commentBody: Didn‚Äôt finish the puzzle yet but wanted to be the first to say it‚Äîwho wanted Wayne‚Äôs World to be BATCAVE or GOTHAMCITY?

Fun theme. Was able to get several of the spanners with no crossings, but the last 25% of the fill was a slog for me. More trivia than I would prefer, but I learned many new things: MEIR, ALUI, CAL, IN A TRICE, GARROTE, TONEARMS, OBIS, SCHIRRA, HALAS, AMBIT, ASWAN, RECTO we're all new to me and took almost all the crossings to get.
There is something perfect about a Sunday crossword filled with bad (meaning good) puns.  Thank you Mr. Ross for a delightful puzzle. I‚Äôll even forgive you for 28A.
This was fun! I loved the puns. And the other fill. Thanks, Randolf! Happy Sunday, y‚Äôall!

What a fun theme from a veteran constructor. I like how each misquote employs a slightly different twist, whether it be changing a letter, dropping a letter or a homophone.  I love TO THINE OWN ELF BE TRUE. So clever.

Welcome back, Randolph. I hope we see you again soon.

A clever and enjoyable puzzle. I've had Cole Porter's "Brush Up Your Shakespeare" stuck in my head ever since I saw the title.

I found this a fun, invigorating puzzle.  I got all the misquoted Shakespeare lines with no cheating.  I came SO close to a cheat-free puzzle.  But it was all filled in and I heard no music of completion.  So I looked up various words about which I wasn't 100% certain. All were correct, until I came to 'Sceirra' for the astronaut.  Alas, it was "SCHIRRA".  I'd had 'abase' for 'ABASH'!  So close, so close!

Thank you Mr. Ross for a real work out!
The SW corner was brutal for me, with INATRICE intersecting with three proper names and enough ambiguity for me to second guess TCM and AMBIT. I was surprised when I got the solved screen!

Our constructor's conversation with his daughter either took place years ago or reminded him of a thought he had years ago. The quote below is from his notes on the 5/21/2017 puzzle, which you might want to do as a follow-up to this one.

Now I'm thinking about "Misquoting Shakespeare" e.g. TWO BS OR NOT TWO BS ‚Äî What the Bard thought about when spelling Caribbean?

Enjoyable. I liked "Good knight sweet prince" and "Fare is foul..." much more than the other misquotes, because they kept the original quotations with a homonymic replacement, whereas the others changed rose to nose, etc., so weren't as clever. I would have preferred all the misquotes be of the first variety. Perhaps that wasn't possible.

Wry being "twisted" surprised me, but of course the constructor is correct. I went down the ety-hole and found this online:

"WRY...1520s, of the neck, face, features, "abnormally bent, distorted, somewhat twisted to one side," from obsolete verb wry "to contort, to twist or turn the neck, deviate from a straight course," Middle English wrien, from Old English wrigian "to turn, bend, move, go," from Proto-Germanic *wrig-.

"This is reconstructed in Watkins to be from PIE *wreik- "to turn" (source also of Greek rhoikos "crooked," Lithuanian rai≈°as "lame, limping"), from root *wer- (2) "to turn, bend."

Figuratively, of words, thoughts, etc., "devious in course or purpose, ill-natured," from 1590s. In reference to a smile by 1883. The original sense is preserved in awry.

"Germanic cognates include Old Frisian wrigia "to bend," Middle Low German wrich "turned, twisted." "

There you go. So a wry eel would be eelier than your plain-spoken eel. I

Some lovely words in this one: garrotte, parapet, trice, Halas, Odette, Aswan. I had "Dahl" before Baum, since those oompa-loompas are quite munchkiness. Dag.

I'm done! See, this is what happens when I finish a Sunday puzzle so crazy quickly, I still have silly energy. 

Anyhow, fun puzzle done in very well faster than average, though there was a FARE amount of things I didn't know... found the crosses very friendly, even in a little twisty for me lower left corner, my final area: AMB??, ?ONEARMS, ??AT?ICE. But, it all worked out. R seemed the most likely completer for Wally's name, then it seemed likely to be INATRICE, which gave me AMBI? and ?ONEARMS. I mean, I know what they are but I didn't know their name. T made the most sense even though I'd swear I've not heard of AMBIT. But, my dunce's music played and here I was, ONEARTH.

Very fun theme, I'm always good with groaners, engaging, and education. If crosswords be the food of love, play on!

I absolutely loved this puzzle!  FAREISFOULANDFOWLISFAIR was just delightful.

I got a bit tripped up in SW, 88D, 96D, and 107D were all unknown to me, and I had ONATRICE (The Tempest) down before INATRICE (Twelfth Night).  If it weren't a Shakespeare puzzle, I don't think I would've thought of that particular idiom at all.  

That said, SW doesn't seem like it was difficult per se, 121A would've unlocked it easily if I were about 20 years older... or if I bought a record player to actually use those limited edition vinyls singers keep selling me and "let the sounds of music creep in [my] ears" once in a while.

Loved the puns and, thankfully, managed to guess most without too many crosses ‚Äî definitely made the puzzle more manageable! Where I really got tripped up was IN A TRICE and TONE ARMS crossing AMBIT, ASWAN, SCHIRRA, and the Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs T[MC/CM]. I had hazy memories of ASWAN and wanted to believe the record part would end in ARMS, but my lack of certainty (paired with total lack of knowledge of the idiom IN A TRICE or the word AMBIT) made that spot alone take something like 10 minutes. Luckily I eventually just went with my gut, and the music played!

I love crosswords, Shakespeare, and cornball humor, so I savored this Sunday gem.  Having looked at the title, I had a general idea of what to expect of the theme clues and answer, but could see that I‚Äôd have to be patient and wait for some crosses.  I broke through with TWOBSORNOTTWOBS, and the rest became clear in short order. My favorite: FAREISFOULANDFOWLISFAIR - nice use of of a pair of homophones.

My only nits: ONEARTH for here (not a fan of clues of that strained ilk); EELIER (just because).  On the other hand, WESTERNS for Wayne‚Äôs World was clever, and made me smile when it finally became clear.  I pictured the Duke saying to me, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a persistent cuss, pilgrim.‚Äù

That was a blast!!!

I don't have a pun, but one of my favorite Shakespeare lines is "when sorrows come, they come not single spies, but in battalions".  In my mind that conjures up that scene in "Jason and the Argonauts" when all the skeletons come out of the ground with swords.

That image comes to me often these days.

And it's such a great observation--it never seems that problems come at a steady, handleable pace.

But in the meantime I just had a flashback to my college days when I wrote two spoofs on Shakespeare. One was a WESTERN (‚ÄúRodeo and Lariat‚Äù) and the other was a film noir take on Hamlet (‚ÄúTo Be and Be Not‚Äù). Anyway, I don‚Äôt remember much and don‚Äôt want to dig them up, but I do remember this line: ‚ÄúWhat light through yonder window bakes? It is the yeast, and Lariat is the bun.‚Äù

On the subject of Shakespeare, I recommend a play called "The Compleat Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged)". https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vd4h16DWpdU It's an absolutely uproarious three person (all male in most productions) play which purports to "cover" all of Shakespeare, even if it does combine all the comedies into one basic plot, and the sonnets are simply printed out and passed from one audience member to the next.

Two years ago, I got together with 4 of my high school friends (Martin Van Buren HS, Class of 1973). We were discussing The NY Times crossword and one friend mentioned that our 11th grade trigonometry teacher Randy Ross was a crossword constructor and was a regular contributor to the NY Times. 

Mr Ross was an amazing math teacher, loved and respected by his students. I myself retired recently as a math teacher, and I can only hope that I will be remembered half as fondly by my students as Mr Ross is remembered by us.

Mixed bag for me. Some really fun and clever word play, but also a good few very tenuous links between the cluing and solution. I‚Äôm never too bothered about obscure trivia though, good to learn little gems even if you do have to look it up.
Really fun puzzle that didn't feel like it was too full of crosswordese. A hard feat!! Stretched my Shakespeare knowledge but was still able to get all the themed clues.

Many years ago I was invited with a group of friends to a mutual friend‚Äôs apartment for dinner. The hostess allowed us to park in her inside parking spot. At the end of the evening my friends and I headed for the elevator only to discover that there were two parking levels -B1 and B2, and we didn‚Äôt know which level we were on. Without missing a beat, I pointed to the elevator buttons and said to my friends ‚ÄúB2 or not B2. That is the question!‚Äù 

Yes, it is a true story.
if you didnt get tonearm youre just not old enough to be up this late.

Anyone else think of the oldie about the woman asking the postman when her package from the photographer would arrive, and he replied,  "I really don't know, but don't worry. Someday your prints will come."

I‚Äôm presently on a tour of Egypt and yesterday stood on the top of the Aswan Dam after visiting the fabulous Abu Simbal monument. I just love it when this sort of thing happens, and I see a little piece of my life experience in the puzzle.

Randolph is a Times crossword powerhouse, with 118 puzzles over 34 years.  Those puzzles include more than a thousand answer debuts, and 74 themes.  Standing-O, sir!

I found today's puzzle fun, trying to get the theme answers with as few crosses as possible.  I loved seeing PARAPET, AMBIT, and GARROTE, gorgeous words that don‚Äôt come around that often.  I liked seeing OPI, ORI and wannabe OBIS, not to mention semordnilaps GAB and BAG, and same-row rhymers ODETTE and BETTE.

Once again you made me smile and satisfied my brain‚Äôs workout ethic, Randolph.  And I look forward to next time.  Thank you!

I enjoyed this puzzle quite a bit. For a while I thought I might end up with a personal best but ran into a couple snags and finished a few minutes over my best time. 
Puzzles that rely on puns for their themes always make me think of my father, who passed away 41 years ago at 60. Often, if he was home for dinner (uncommon as he was a doctor who was a workaholic‚Äîhence his four coronaries) he expected me to engage in a pun-duel, in which he‚Äôd make a pun and I had to respond with a pun related to his, then he would have to build on that, then I would, continuing until one of us (usually me) would surrender. Mind you, this started when I was perhaps 13 or 14. Later, some years after his death, I came to understand that he was quite shy, even to the point of having no idea how to talk to the son who bore his name, and so puns were his way in.

Caitlin's quip about roses and noses made me think of this old ditty from "Singin' in the Rain":

"Moses supposes his toeses are roses,
but Moses supposes erroneously.
For Moses he knowses his toeses aren't roses
as Moses supposes his toeses to be."

The most superficial knowledge of Shakespeare will enable you to do this puzzle¬†with ease and instant recognition.¬† Well, maybe not the most¬†superficial knowledge, but knowledge that is nonetheless pretty darned superficial.

My favorite answer was FARE IS FOUL AND FOWL IS FAIR -- even though the phrase had to be broken up into three (3!) parts.¬† But my favorite clue¬†was the one for A NOSE BY ANY OTHER NAME.

I thought the initial impulse behind the puzzle would have been the FARE themer.¬† That the constructor would have thought of the double homophone.¬† But, no, it was serendipitous:¬† Randolph asked someone whether Caribbean was spelled with one B or two -- and then had to rephrase it in the way that appears in the grid.¬† (Randolph's Constructor¬†Notes are interesting and you might want to take a look at them if you haven't already.

I found most of the fill quite easy, except for TONE ARMS.¬† (I think that's right, but forgot to check.)¬† I'm of the advanced age that has owned record players much of my life, even though I gather that's not the way anyone listens to music anymore, and I never called the thing that holds the needle and goes up and down, on and off the record, anything but an ARM?¬† Anyone heard of a TONE ARM?¬† Everyone but me?

Could this be the same man who constructed a puzzle, ca. 1990, featuring pop song titles grammatically corrected? I loved that one so much I've never forgotten it. The only specific entry I remember is "To Whom Can I Turn."

I've constructed a whole bunch of puzzles. None have been published because they all stink. Turns out, it's easy to make a puzzle ‚Äì if I can do it, you can do it. But to make a puzzle like this takes that special something that few constructors have. I don't know what it is but by golly Randolph, you sure have it by the bucketful. Mindbogglingly well done.

One more puzzle find. A Monday from November 12, 2001 by Janice M. Putney. One thing that was quite surprising to me is that all of the theme answers were 15 letters. This reminds me of a dreadful joke that my mother utterly loved, you need some deep Shakespeare to get this:

A trucker gets a job driving through the Australian outback but finds he can't stay awake for the whole 15-hour drive. It seems many other truckers can't either, because right in the middle of nowhere is a truck-stop in a small two-horse town named with the hard Australian sarcasm as "Mercy Truckstop".

Arriving at midnight, he asks for some tea to keep himself awake.

Instead of a pot they bring out a huge pan, filled with tea, and laying in the middle of it is a dead koala bear - fur, face, and all. He is shocked and asks what the deal is.

The server smiles and says, "just try it, hon."

So he takes out a spoon, tastes just a bit and it's not only utterly delicious, it's got the caffeine kick of a thousand mules. 

The pan is so deep, he not only can have two cups at the counter, he can fill his entire thermos.

Canisters in hand, he heads off on his route, wide awake and happy.

On the return trip, he pulls into the truckstop, feeling tired but happy because he knows he will be able to do this run indefinitely because of the truckstop.

He walks in and asks for the tea, the server nods knowingly and turns to leave, but he calls out...

"Listen, would it be possible for you to just bring the pan, but leave the bear out?"

To which she turns back and replies with a smile, "I'm sorry sir, the koala tea of mercy is not strained."

@Darren

None of these are made up.  Other than that all words are made up.

TRACER is certainly not obscure; it's the normal word for what you ask them to put on a package that didn't arrive when it was supposed to.  AWOL is Absent Without Leave, a well-known military term for a serious offense.  The question mark you omitted is crucial here; it indicates wordplay.  The soldier is gone, and it is wrong.

You might have a bit of an argument with the other two.  However:

RECTO is a bit niche, but the two sides of a page in a book are called RECTO and verso.  Pages 1, 3, 5, etc., are RECTO; 2, 4, 6, etc. are verso (the reverse).  Obscure in real life, perhaps, but has appeared 116 in the NYT crossword.  Learn it; it will be back. (Verso less so at 31 appearances; the V is less useful.)

IN A TRICE:  A TRICE is a fleeting moment, and has appeared 91 times; the whole phrase only 8 times, lastly in 2012.  I'd say it's a "quaint expression."  

There, you've learned four new words that you're bound to see again.  Or five, including "verso."

commentBody: Andrzej, if I may reply to your comment yesterday... (Time-saver alert: what follows is unrelated to yesterday's or today's puzzle) Regarding children, you took the words right outta my mouth. Complete agreement. Have you heard of the U-shaped (or smile-shaped) happiness curve? Here's Scott Galloway discussing it with Bill Maher on this weekend's Overtime: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Y1nAONKFjY&t=658s Regarding London and, "the dreary Warsaw of the early 90s" - I enjoyed both! I did my fall '94 semester abroad in London (first time outside the US except for a week holiday in The Bahamas). Like many students, we did more traveling than studying. Most used their Eurail passes on the well-worn path through western European countries, but my friend and I, wanting to go where nobody else was going, went to Warsaw. We befriended a pair of identical twins, also uni students, and let them show us around. I remember wondering why so many shops were closed in the middle of the day - they weren't, just looked that way because they kept the lights off (saving power, I guess?). Being students on a budget we lunched every day in the same borscht soup-kitchen - delicious "home" cooking served by the sweetest old ladies with whom we communicated by pointing and pantomime. Good times!

@Bill in Yokohama Yes, I have heard of the happiness curve. The Guardian has covered it many times, for example here: https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/aug/22/research-says-that-your-40s-are-your-unhappiest-age-its-worse-for-millennials Of the people my age-ish that I know and who are parents, many are clearly unhappy, constantly bickering, and even those who look OK are always busy, all their lives reduced to work and caring for their children. They only ever get time for themselves when they dump the children on somebody. You enjoyed Warsaw because you were young and adventurous, and didn't actually have to live there. It was dirty, grey, dangerously polluted, riddled with both petty and violent crime, and getting worse every year, up until the end of the decade. When I returned to Warsaw from my month in London as a 13 year old in 1993 I literally cried for a week, despairing over how horrible my home country and city were. It's only now, over 30 years later, that I am finally beginning to enjoy living here. Experiencing Poland in the 1990s was one of the main reasons I never really became a Polish patriot. You just can't love or feel proud of a place that could get that bad. I've enjoyed vacations in many places I would never, ever like to live.

@Andrzej

Another statistic I find telling; when *parents* are asked, "What is the ideal number of children to have?" 10% answer, "none." If 10% are willing to admit this, the actual figure is of course likely higher. I've seen estimates as high as 20%
@Bill in Yokohama That is another thing covered by The Guardian on several occassions, for example here: https://www.theguardian.com/wellness/2024/sep/26/regret-having-children-no-kids-cultural-taboo

@Sam Lyons

Right? I certainly know mine.

@Andrzej

Yes, and I respect that. What I don‚Äôt respect is the first woman in The Guardian story who reportedly knew she‚Äôd made a mistake as soon as she got pregnant, yet went on and had kid #2.
@Andrzej. The advantage of age is that I was familiar with both.  The disadvantages come with pop culture, but I'm hanging in!

@Andrzej I'm a big fan of puns so had a great time with this puzzle. While I like puns, I'm not usually quick or bright enough to come up with my own. Fortunately my lack of qualification for Mensa membership doesn't bother me.

@Sam Lyons et alii
Well, guys....wow.  I can't tell you how many people expressed shock, surprise, and even reproof that we actually went ahead and had a second child after our first was found to have multiple birth defects.  (I even had a nurse ask, "Did you keep her?")  
And  so far, I don't see any mention or acknowledgement or discussion of the most basic thing:  attachment.  (Hormones are said to play a part, but it's not the only explanation for parental love.)  A child in utero is already very real to a woman--moving, kicking, reacting, napping, and as seen on ultrasound, sucking his/her thumb.  
     People do have inborn natures...and there are those who just are not nurturing, and it's just as well if they know themselves and take that into account.  
I have to stop here, but ...  how sad is this thread?

@Mean Old Lady

Why is it sad? Like you said, people know themselves. Acting upon what one strongly feels is the right choice for them surely can't be sad?

Despite having experienced a nurturing childhood, I have always felt zero inclination to be a parent. While many people instinctively love babies and find them cute, I'm borderline disgusted by them. Elementary school kids tire me out, and teenagers are monsters best avoided. The people I meet at uni when they're 18 or 19 are generally quite cool. But getting there... Nah.

Also, the largely carefree life I lead is 100% incompatible with having children - I would have to change literally everything about it. I might end up miserable, like those 15% or so of people who regret having kids. The risk is just too high. But that's me, and apparently Bill in Yokohama too. I'm not saying we are better or worse than people who want to have kids. We are just different. I'm not feeling sad about my choice, at all.

And I'm not a psychopath. I understand what feelings parents have for their children - being my father is obviously the most important thing in my dad's life, and I love being his son. But even so, I just don't see myself in that parental role.

And finally, I really do believe humanity is heading for distaster - within decades, not centuries. To bring a child into a world like this?

@Sam Lyons
Haven't read the Guardian item but I point out that no birth control method is 100% except abstinence. She may have made her best efforts and still ended up pregnant.

@Andrzej
In my rush to deal with an interruption, I may not have chosen the best word (sad only had three letters!)   I just found the 'discussion' fairly lopsided.  

People choose to forego having children (or have no choice in the matter) and live lives of accomplishment, joy, and fulfillment--as you have.  It would be untrue and unfair to assign any sort of judgment or air of superiority to my words, I believe.  It's certainly not how I feel.  

We chose to have children, and.....it has been an unexpected life.  When I hear, "We don't care if it's a boy or a girl, as long as it's healthy," and I think to myself, "You don't get to pick."  Not in a malicious way!  Just, "Life is what happens while you were making other plans."  
My career arc, my ambitions, my income--a tsunami couldn't have been as thoroughly destructive, but humans are oddly capable of making the best of things.
"A world like this?"  When has it ever been easy, safe, glorious?  During the Black Death? The rise of the Third Reich?  
And child-rearing doesn't last forever...From birth through to the second year of college (after which neither child was 'home' except for visits) added up to about 25 years--and left a lot of years for my writing, my art, and more.  

Parenthood is an opportunity to learn and grow--not what I hoped, not what I expected, but also not what I regret.

@Andrzej As for your nihilism üòÅ, Kurtzgesagt would like a word with you here: Start at 11:10 if you‚Äôre short on time https://youtu.be/LxgMdjyw8uw?si=ei58J4tFHWe0Ftx- https://youtu.be/MBRqu0YOH14?si=A0FCP0sBtDtuB-wl

@Liza The trick to getting the theme for a Sunday is looking at the title of the grid :)
If you're playing on the app you can see it by clicking on the info button at the top

@Liza

All it takes is practice, and an open mind.

When I started doing these puzzles in mid-2023, most themes stumped me, and I just could not get my head around Thursdays. Within 12 or 18 months, I began appreciating the Thursday gimmicks, and by then I was almost always able to grasp them while solving. Now, after almost 30 months, I generally like Thursday puzzles best of all.

Given you're a native English speaker, you will probably get there faster than I did.

@Liza
I'm fairly new. I start by doing as much as I can over the whole crossword. Then I go to the Wordplay. I used to hardly ever get the theme, and still don't always bother about it. This Sunday's was one of my favourites.

There are always some clues I just don't know (brand names, names of sports team) and some where I don't know what the clue means or the solution! Some I look up online, and if that's no help, people on the forum are exceptionally helpful! 

There are what they call "fill" clues (unknown concept  to the UK solver) which you gradually learn - OPI for ESSIE or nail varnish (they are quite random), SSN or SSNS for Social Security Number(s), OREO biscuits - there are dozens. 

Sometimes people can get quite heated eg the spelling of octopus ..... mostly politics is avoided.

I don't know if you know The Guardian Quick Crossword, there is a very friendly forum there - sometimes they call it The Caff. 

The forum here has restored my faith in the USA.
@Riccardo I think that is only on Sunday.  Thursday ‚Äòs didn't have a theme listed. but thanks anyway.

@Jane Wheelaghan That is how I‚Äôve been trying to do them too, fill in what I can without spoilers.  I have to look up any sports clue though (absolutely no knowledge of that).    I‚Äôve noticed on the NYTs archive OREO and ORCA are used a lot! I will check out the Guardian one too, thanks for the tips.

@Liza

Welcome to the greatest forum in galactic history, more or less.

Everyone does things differently here, and that's a plus.  Personally I never read Wordplay or the comments until I've done the puzzle, and that is 100% my preference and it is in no way better or worse than any one else's preference.

But the bottom line is just go at these puzzles over and over and over in whatever way you feel you're developing the best.  Often you'll feel like you mastered the puzzle, sometimes you'll feel the puzzle mastered you.  At those times learn as much as you can about what you missed in terms of clue trickery, or theme  hints, and the like.  

And if you're like me vent a little in the comments, within the limits of respect for the people who produce the puzzle.  I've been through several diatribe/apology cycles.

There are no hard and fast rules.  Often rules we think are know were never rules at all.  But some rules are pretty ruley.  Hard to really know for sure.    

Everybody learns differently.

Determining themes was difficult for me at first.  After a couple of years I'm getting better, but am still a long, long way from the true masters of the art, many of whom post here.   

Read their comments and they'll help you learn, in some mysterious way.

And have fun.

@Liza
I started during Covid lockdown and was hooked. I‚Äôm constantly amazed at how much I learn about different cultures through the grids; North American, Spanish (there‚Äôs a LOT of Spanish) South American, Chinese, the list is endless.
As far as how to solve goes, I think it was the sainted Deb Amlen (Wordplay writer) who said it doesn‚Äôt matter how you do it. It‚Äôs your crossword, do what works for you. 

My personal method involves attacking the grid until I hit a wall, usually US specific sports, names, products etc which we non Americans couldn‚Äôt be expected to just know. I then read Wordplay for help, moving onto the comments if needed. If all else fails I hit the Check Puzzle button (top right on my iPad) which shows my errors. I gave up trying to maintain a streak long ago and find it much more enjoyable with the pressure off.

The point is, it‚Äôs meant to be fun, so do it anyway you like. As you can see by the replies you‚Äôve got, people here are lovely; so friendly and helpful. With the way things are, it‚Äôs  heartwarming to read the great comments from fellow cruciverbalists around the world. Welcome to the community.

@Helen Wright

To give credit where credit is due, the quote is not originally Deb‚Äôs, though I‚Äôm sure she borrowed it from time to time. The second editor, two before Shortz, Will Weng, said it in an article written as a valedictory when he left the position.

@Liza

I‚Äôve been doing these since the start of pandemic. Early on, I‚Äôd get stuck a lot, so I‚Äôd allow myself to cheat in roughly this order:

1. Read the Wordplay column for any freebies
2. Look up the Wikipedia article for applicable unknown answers. Read the entire article
3. Read the Wordplay comments and hope someone mentioned whatever I‚Äôm stuck on
4. Google
5. Check answer key (usually revealing a typo somewhere)

Over time, you start to get feel for how the puzzles are constructed and get better at guessing answers you don‚Äôt really know.

I had failed to keep up with the previous generation of music-playing devices and the one before that, and now there are newer ones still.  I was told just yesterday that no one in the building could burn an extra CD for me of "Fergie, the 10-minute musical."  Much of my other work is online, but this was a one-time BMI presentation for which only this one CD exists.  I wanted to send it to someone who had never heard it who lives in CA.  The violinist who's playing in a major Broadway musical right and seemed like the most musical person in the building  looked at me as if I'd asked him for an item from the 16th century.  The handyman who was standing in the lobby next to him is the most-tech-savvy person I know in the building.  I smiled sweetly and said: "I guess I'll have to tip you, Franklin", and he looked completely lost and just shrugged.  Then both said the same thing to me: "There's no point in burning a CD for you since no one uses a CD player anymore."

As I say, I'm three generations behind the times.  And I guess no one who's not actually in my apartment with me will ever hear "Fergie: the 10-minute musical."

And creating a puzzle is hard work and not terribly well compensated, except for the "reputation" that one gets in this community.  "Always speak kindly of the constructors," is my mantra.

My "beef" with Sunday puzzles is that I almost always have a typo and "flyspecking" the 21-by-21 grid is time-consuming and no fun at all.
Today, somehow, I put in a zero (0) instead of an O.  How did that happen???

I like to remind myself that in the days of solving on paper, I would never even notice a typo (or even an error); there was no music and no gold star.  I'd just pat myself on the back and get on with my life.
